body:
I was following the  [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)  in order to start contributing to the flutter plugin in Intellij IDEA.

I was able to follow all steps before getting gradle build error at:

> Open flutter-intellij project in IntelliJ (select and open the directory of the flutter-intellij repository). Build it using  `Build`  |  `Build Project`

step from  [CONTRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#flutter-plugin-development).

<details>

comment_data.body:
You are missing some symbolic links.
   > Source directory 'E:\flutter-intellij\flutter-idea\gen' is not a directory.
   > Source directory 'E:\flutter-intellij\flutter-idea\gen' is not a directory.
   > Source directory 'E:\flutter-intellij\flutter-idea\src\main\resources' is not a directory.

These should all be symlinks to the same-named directory in the root directory. You probably have more missing symlinks. You are possibly the first person to attempt working on the plugin using Windows, so there may be more issues down the road. However, if you want to continue just keep asking questions. It would be great to get PRs from someone using Windows!

Our directory structure is odd, for historical reasons. We started the project using *.iml files to define modules. When Kotlin adoption increased, we realized we needed a Gradle model in order to compile Kotlin. That's why we have the symlinks. Building the plugin and running unit tests require the Gradle model.

You might have better results if you try opening as a legacy project rather than as a Gradle project. I forget the details but I think if you use `File > Open...` and select the `flutter-intellij` directory, IntelliJ will give you the option of opening as legacy or Gradle. When I want to open as Gradle I always select the top-level `build.gradle` file. The legacy layout does not use symlinks. Another option, that I have not tried, is to open the Project Structure editor and import the module. In that case you would select the `flutter-intellij.iml` file.

One more thing. I just updated CONTRIBUTING.md today, so make sure you have the latest. The latest includes a mention of IntelliJ 2020.3 and Java 11, neither of which were in the previous version. I'd recommend updating all your software to the latest versions, too.

I'll leave this open so you have a single place to check for questions.

Hello @stevemessick,

Thank you for providing the solution.

Also, I have updated to latest versions for IntelliJ (v203.7717.56) & Java (v11.0.10)

As you mentioned, I opened the project as a `legacy project` in IntelliJ IDEA and was able to complete the [Flutter plugin development](https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#flutter-plugin-development) section.

Now, I was working on the [Running plugin tests](https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#running-plugin-tests) section. Specifically on the Unit Testing part. I know that these tests do not currently run on Windows. But, I would be happy to provide my contribution in including them on Windows.

Following are the queries:
> -   In the same dialog (Run/Debug Configurations) expand Defaults node, find JUnit under it and paste VM Options to the corresponding field

In the above step, I didn't see any `Defaults` node in Windows. Instead I had `Templates` node. Are they same? Please check out below image:

![Run-Debug Configurations_Templates](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38665793/112467958-b4e8e880-8d8d-11eb-9291-2e6d0ff3e8f9.png)

>  -   Repeat the same with Working directory field - it must point to intellij-community/bin

(from [CONRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#running-plugin-tests))

In this step, what does `intellij-community/bin` imply? 
Does it mean 

~/flutter-intellij/bin (The bin folder under repository)
**OR**
 ~/Program Files/IntelliJ IDEA Community Edition 2020.3.1/bin (The bin folder under IntelliJ IDEA software) ?
<hr>

> If running the full unit test suite fails, check the run configuration and verify that 'Use classpath of module' is set to `flutter-intellij.test`. 

(from [CONRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#running-plugin-tests))

In this step, does `Use classpath of module` mean selecting `flutter-intellij.test` from 

`JUnit -> Flutter Tests (unit) -> Use classpath of module` 
**OR**
`Templates -> JUnit -> Use classpath of module` ? (check below images)

![Use classpath of module](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38665793/112468263-08f3cd00-8d8e-11eb-9387-cb477473b3f6.png)

**OR**
![Use classpath of module2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38665793/112468286-10b37180-8d8e-11eb-9db5-28a61a57639a.png)
<hr>



> To run unit tests on the command line: ``` bin/plugin test ``` (from [CONRIBUTING.md](https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#running-plugin-tests))

I was not able to run this command on `Command prompt` on Windows.

It would be great to get the unit tests running on Windows. We have made a couple attempts to run them on various CI frameworks but the errors are too time-consuming to debug in batch mode.

> I didn't see any Defaults node in Windows. Instead I had Templates node. Are they same?

Yes. Our instructions need to be updated. This whole section is wrong. You should not need to modify templates. The run config is already defined, checked into the github repo. Just select the run config named "Flutter Tests (unit)". You can use the Copy Configuration button to duplicate it if you want to change it to run a subset of tests. (Pardon me if I'm stating the obvious.)

Our tests seem to be out of date for running in IntelliJ. I just tried and got lots of failures that look like configuration problems.

We generally run the unit tests on the github bots, when we create a PR or merge one. Those work. Those are run via command line. `bin/plugin` is a simple shell script to run the plugin management tool, which does builds, tests, and a few other things. If you have `dart` on your path you can run the tool by:

`dart tool\plugin\bin\main.dart help`

Change `help` to some other command to run it. Note: the `build` command is obsolete. Use `make` instead.

For you to be able to run unit tests from the command line you will need to resolve the Gradle errors. All the symbolic links will be required. Here is the full list:

[list.txt](https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/files/6174019/list.txt)

The question I have is, why did the symbolic links not get created for you? We've onboarded several people since the links were added and have had not problems.

dart tool\plugin\bin\main.dart help
I pretty much got it. 

Also, talking about symbolic links, I have appended the presence of them in my system on each line in the same txt file.

[list.txt](https://github.com/flutter/flutter-intellij/files/6191617/list.txt)

So, I think symbolic links did get generated.

The `build` directory gets created when the plugin is built, so you're not missing anything.

We're back to the beginning. I wonder if Gradle is not able to use symbolic links on Windows?
> Source directory 'E:\flutter-intellij\flutter-idea\gen' is not a directory.
> Source directory 'E:\flutter-intellij\flutter-idea\gen' is not a directory.
> Source directory 'E:\flutter-intellij\flutter-idea\src\main\resources' is not a directory.

You have the symlinks, so that's not the problem. Is there a more recent version of Gradle available? Are you using the `.\gradlew` (Gradle wrapper) that comes with the plugin source? It may need to be updated.

The gradle version is the latest stable version `v6.8.3`. More details are mentioned in the first comment of this issue.

It looks like symlinks are a problem for Gradle. You might try some of the suggestions mentioned in this issue:
https://github.com/gradle/gradle/issues/9077

- Use JDK 13 or later
- Switch Windows to Developer Mode
- Use `cmd.exe` not PowerShell

I'm not a Windows expert so I don't have suggestions other than what I see on the web. I saw a reference to something called a "directory junction" that might be related.

Use JDK 13 or later
